channel.title: Climate Change - Digg
channel.description: Climate Change on Digg: the best articles, videos, tweets, and original content that the web is talking about right now

item.title: The Uplifting Tale Of These Tiny Island Foxes, Nearly Wiped Out By Disaster
item.description: Earth Day began after a catastrophe off California. Leadership and science restored nature and hope through years of despair and controversy.

item.title: Coronavirus Is Reducing CO2. Why That's Worrisome
item.description: A growing number of estimates say global carbon dioxide emissions could fall 5% in 2020. That would be the largest annual drop on record. But climate researchers say there is little reason for celebration.
item.kicker: CAN WE PLEASE CATCH A BREAK? ANYWHERE?

item.title: Melting Ice Reveals A 'Lost' Viking-Era Pass In Norway's Mountains
item.description: Artifacts show people used the route for 1,000 years — then abandoned it, possibly amid a plague.

item.title: Climate Change Won't Stop For The Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The next several months could bring hurricanes, floods and fire, on top of the pandemic currently raging through the country. How do you shelter in place during an evacuation?

item.title: A Biblical Nightmare Strikes The Horn Of Africa
item.description: Locust swarms are multiplying in eastern Africa as farmers plant their next harvest and the coronavirus threat grows.

item.title: Inside A Cross-Border Battle Against Cancer In Ontario's Rust Belt
item.description: Two communities — one in Canada, one in the US — share both a border along the St. Marys River and a toxic legacy that has contributed to high rates of cancer. Now the towns are banding together to fight a ferrochrome plant planned to process chromite from Ontario's Ring of Fire.

item.title: Do Personal Carbon Credits Work?
item.description: I'm paying Project Wren $15.70 per month to offset my carbon footprint. Can it do more than absolve my guilt?

item.title: The Pandemic Is Turning The Natural World Upside Down
item.description: Widespread social-distancing measures have produced some jarring effects across land, air and sea.

item.title: Rising Tides, Troubled Waters: The Future Of Our Ocean
item.description: The ocean is undergoing unprecedented changes. What does it mean for marine life, the planet and us?

item.title: Oceans Can Be Restored To Former Glory Within 30 Years, Say Scientists
item.description: Major review reports recovery of marine life, but a redoubling of efforts is still needed.

item.title: The Next Pandemic Could Be Hiding In The Arctic Permafrost
item.description: Global warming could unearth ancient microbes. Will we be as unprepared as we were for the coronavirus?

item.title: A Fragmented Novel For The End Of The World
item.description: Jenny Offill's "Weather" captures the dread of a global catastrophe.

item.title: The Baller
item.description: Can attitude help save the planet? A frightened climate reporter meets an ex-basketball player with a serious game plan.
item.kicker: 'THIS PROBLEM IS SO EASY TO SOLVE, IT'S ABSURD'

item.title: The Secret To Curbing Farm Emissions Is Buried In The Stone Age
item.description: When farmers reduce tilling, plant cover crops and speckle their steads with livestock and trees, they're helping fight climate change and bolstering their bottom lines.

item.title: Wyoming Confronts Its Wind-Powered Destiny
item.description: The Cowboy State should be a renewable energy juggernaut, but it's dominated by fossils fuels. Next step: Thinking of the future instead of digging up the past.

item.title: This Is What The Earth's Climate Will Look Like In 2050
item.description: The future under climate change can seem frighteningly vague and variable. A top climatologist explains what to expect in 2050.

item.title: The Climate Crisis Will Be Just As Shockingly Abrupt
item.description: The coronavirus isn't a reason to put climate policy on hold. It's a warning of the calamities ahead.

item.title: Coronavirus Has Slashed Global Air Pollution. This Interactive Map Shows How
item.description: The covid-19 pandemic has changed the world, grinding to a halt increasingly large geographic areas and portions of the economy in an effort to slow the virus' spread.

item.title: The Movement To Preserve Silence As A Natural Resource
item.description: Preservationists have created the first "quiet park," with hardly a peep from humankind. Now they're hoping the tourists will come and spread the message of quiet.

item.title: The Great Lakes Depend On Ice. This Winter, They Barely Froze
item.description: The region comes alive during winter. But both culture and the economy suffer when the cold doesn't come.
item.kicker: THE COLD NEVER BOTHERED THEM ANYWAY

item.title: California Power Company Pleads Guilty To Manslaughter In Paradise Fire
item.description: PG&E pleads guilty to criminal charges in the deadly 2018 fire and will pay about $3.5m in fines.

item.title: Meet The Christians Giving Up Carbon And Single-Use Plastic For Lent
item.description: The biblical mandate of "creation care" is taking on new urgency as the planet warms.

item.title: Meet The Christians Giving Up Carbon And Single-Use Plastic For Lent
item.description: The biblical mandate of "creation care" is taking on new urgency as the planet warms.
item.kicker: COULD WE JUST DO THIS... ALL THE TIME

item.title: Air Pollution Falls As Coronavirus Slows Travel, But Scientists Warn Of Longer-Term Threat To Climate Change Progress
item.description: Scientists argue that the long-term impact of the coronavirus pandemic on climate change will depend on how countries and corporations respond to an economic crisis.

item.title: Sudden Ancient Global Warming Event Traced To Magma Flood
item.description: A study has cemented the link between an intense global warming episode 56 million years ago and volcanism in the North Atlantic, with implications for modern climate change.

item.title: Rupaul Has A Fracking Empire On His Wyoming Ranch
item.description: As if we needed any more evidence that the world is a psychedelic hellscape, RuPaul—yeah, that RuPaul— and his husband are making money off the fracking industry. Yes, yes, this sounds like a wild conspiracy theory. But we've got the receipts.
item.kicker: A LITTLE SIDE BUSINESS, AS A TREAT

item.title: There Is Only One Right Plan For Fracking
item.description: Solving the climate crisis will require politicians to aspire to new levels of ambition, free themselves from the fossil fuel industry and listen to the science.

item.title: Social Distancing? You Might Be Fighting Climate Change, Too
item.description: Isolation and other shifts in behavior during the coronavirus outbreak could also alter our greenhouse gas emissions. But will the changes stick?

item.title: 'If You're Not Sweating' In This Town, 'There's Something Wrong'
item.description: In Marble Bar, which claims to be Australia's hottest town, the temperature hit at least 113 degrees on 32 days this summer. Some residents worry that "there's got to be a point where you actually start to cook."

item.title: What Do We Do With Feelings Now That They Don't Matter Anymore?
item.description: Sarah Miller thinks about climate change and other current horrors, and what it's like just being sad forever.

item.title: All The Ways I Failed Miserably Trying To Live Plastic-Free For A Week
item.description: No matter how hard I tried, plastic kept sneaking its way back into my life.

item.title: Can Redwoods Save The World?
item.description: Not by themselves, but the Archangel Ancient Tree Archive is out to show how they can help.

item.title: The Great Alaskan Guessing Game
item.description: Last year the jackpot in the Nenana Ice Classic was $311,652. Watching ice melt just got really interesting.

item.title: How Humanity Could Last Forever
item.description: Our species will face no shortage of existential risks in the coming decades. Can we sidestep them and carry on?
item.kicker: DON'T WANNA LIVE LIKE THIS, BUT DON'T WANNA DIE

item.title: In Dozens Of Cities East Of The Mississippi, Winter Never Really Happened
item.description: Something called the Arctic oscillation helped keep the polar vortex at bay. And then there's climate change.

item.title: The Huge Holes In The EU's New Climate Law Proposal
item.description: The European Commission's climate law proposal would commit the 27 nations in the EU to become carbon neutral by 2050. But it's got some pretty serious shortcomings.

item.title: The Congo Rainforest Is Losing Its Ability To Absorb Carbon Dioxide. That's Bad For Climate Change
item.description: Like the Amazon, the Congo Basin rainforest is turning from carbon "sink" to source, new study says.

item.title: The Great Barrier Reef Is Heading For A Mass Bleaching Of Unprecedented Scale
item.description: Forecasts for the largest living structure on Earth have become "devastating," scientists say, and the coral carnage will be even more widespread than the last mass bleaching in 2016-2017.

item.title: Climate Change Could Make These Common Foods Poisonous
item.description: The effects of climate change could cause many common crops to shift their chemical makeup, often in ways that are toxic to humans.

item.title: Plane Contrails Have A Surprising Effect On Global Warming
item.description: The wispy ice clouds formed by jet exhaust help trap heat near the Earth's surface. But small changes in altitude can dampen the effect, a study says.

item.title: How Heat Pumps Can Help Fight Global Warming
item.description: These ultra-efficient systems could massively reduce our emissions from heating and cooling buildings.

item.title: The Razor-Sharp Guilt Trips Of Alex Garland's Science Fiction
item.description: Though the plots of Garland's work — "Ex Machina," "Annihilation," and FX's new miniseries "Devs" — are different, their messages are similar: Earth is broken, and we are the ones who broke it.

item.title: Shell Has A Plan To Profit From Climate Change
item.description: The fossil-fuel companies expect to profit from climate change. I went to a private planning meeting and took notes.

item.title: Moscow Didn't Get A Winter This Year, Setting A Major Record
item.description: Russia holds a place in our cultural imagination as being cold as balls. But with climate change, past results don't guarantee future performance — or even present performance.
item.kicker: I SAID OOOH, IT'S BALMY IN HERE

item.title: Think Flash Floods Are Bad? Buckle Up For Flash Droughts
item.description: Scientists are trying to figure out a phenomenon called a flash drought, which forms in as little as two weeks.

item.title: How Beef Eaters In Cities Are Draining Rivers In The American West
item.description: In some western river basins, over 50 percent of the water goes to cattle feed, fodder for cows that end up as burgers in major US cities. To save rivers, scientists suggest paying farmers to not farm.

item.title: Toxic Shellfish Are Hurting The Alaskan Alutiiq In Ways That Threaten Their Survival
item.description: Indigenous Alaskans — a quarter of whom live below the poverty line — turn to the ocean for their daily sustenance. But now, new highs in temperature are affecting their shellfish in the region with fatal levels of toxicity.

item.title: What A Green New Deal Would Look Like In Every State
item.description: What if the proposed Green New Deal were real? Here's a state-by-state breakdown of potential environmental projects, from Alabama to Wyoming.
item.kicker: CLEAN AIR AND SO MUCH MORE

item.title: Scientists Are Scrambling To Make Thirsty Crops Love Salt
item.description: Rising soil salinity is a serious, climate change-linked issue that producers are increasingly struggling with.

item.title: Alaskan Roulette
item.description: As warming waters make shellfish toxic, a way of life becomes deadly for native Alaskans.
item.kicker: 'WHEN THE WATER GETS WARM BE CAREFUL'
